title: About
text: My name is Caleb Clark and I am a third year student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. This website was created to highlight some of the stories I have created and help people learn more about college sports. I also play baseball here at UNL and I hope to showcase some data from our season. I am from Canada and I enjoy all things sports. Thank you for clicking on my website and I hope you enjoy these stories!

title: How did Nebraska have success in total rebounding but struggle in offensive rebounding?
text:
During the 2023-2024 men’s college basketball season, the Nebraska Cornhuskers ranked within the top 70 in total rebounds. They worked hard to dominate on the defensive end and it paid off ranking within the top 20. Their issue? Getting second chances on the offensive side. Nebraska ranked 241st in Division one basketball in offensive rebounding and struggled in their biggest moments which led to an early exit in the tournament.
The question is: How can you dominate but also struggle doing the exact same thing but opposite ends of the court?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(waffle)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
#| message: FALSE
basketball <- read_csv("logs24.csv")
big_ten_data <- basketball %>%
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten") %>%
  group_by(Team) %>%
  summarise(
    Total_Offensive_Rebounds = sum(TeamOffRebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
    Total_Rebounds = sum(TeamTotalRebounds, na.rm = TRUE), 
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Rebounds), desc(Total_Offensive_Rebounds))  
waffle_data <- big_ten_data %>%
  select(Team, Total_Rebounds, Total_Offensive_Rebounds) %>%
  gather(key = "Rebound_Type", value = "Rebounds", Total_Rebounds, Total_Offensive_Rebounds) %>%
  arrange(desc(Rebounds))
nu2 <- c("Total Rebounds"=1176, "Offensive Rebounds"=277)
wi2 <- c("Total Rebounds"=1106, "Offensive Rebounds"=309)

iron(
 waffle(nu2/2, 
        rows = 11, 
        title="Nebraska's Total Rebounds vs Offensive Rebounds", 
        xlab="1 square = 2 rebounds", 
        colors = c("black", "red")
        ),
 waffle(wi2/2, 
        rows = 11, 
         title="Wisconsin's Total Rebounds vs Offensive Rebounds", 
        xlab = "1 square = 2 rebounds",
        colors = c("black", "red"),
      
        )
        
)









The Huskers match up nicely against Wisconsin and actually outperform them by 70 rebounds in total. But when you look at the red dots, there is a clear advantage for the Badgers.
How does Nebraska continuously out rebound teams on the defensive side but cannot keep up with them when they change sides. Is it a lack of agressiveness or size?
Speaking of size, let’s compare them to the cream of the crop, the Purdue Boilermakers.


Code
nu<-c("Total Rebounds"= 1176, "Offensive Rebounds"= 277, 273)
pu<-c("Total Rebounds"= 1335, "Offensive Rebounds"=391)
iron(
 waffle(nu/2, 
        rows = 13, 
        title="Nebraska's Total Rebounds vs Offensive Rebounds", 
        xlab="1 square = 2 rebounds", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "white")
        ),
 waffle(pu/2, 
        rows = 13, 
         title="Purdue's Total Rebounds vs Offensive Rebounds", 
        xlab = "1 square = 2 rebounds",
        colors = c("black", "red"),
       )
)









Yikes. Purdue dominated both total rebounds and offensive rebounds vs the Huskers but they had the best rebounder in college basketball in 7’4 inch Zach Edey so it was not a shock to see them with a clear advantage over the Huskers.
But if we were to compare them to the entire Big Ten in both total and offensive rebounds, where would they rank and what can it tell us?


Code
library(tidyverse)
big10 <- basketball |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten")
huskers <- basketball |>
  filter(
    Team == "Nebraska"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=big10, aes(x=reorder(Team, TeamTotalRebounds), weight=TeamTotalRebounds), fill="lightgrey") + 
  geom_bar(data=huskers, aes(x=reorder(Team, TeamTotalRebounds), weight=TeamTotalRebounds), fill="red") +
  coord_flip() +
 labs(
    title = "Box Out! Nebraska controls the paint in their zone",
    subtitle = "Huskers ranked 4th in the Big Ten in total rebounds. Largely due to the defensive end",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Rebounds",
    fill = "Rebound Type",
    caption = "Source | Basketball Reference | By: Caleb Clark"
    
  ) +
  theme_minimal()+
    theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face= "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size=10),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 8),  
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "white"),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "white") 
)









Well this tells me that Coach Fred Hoiberg makes sure that Nebraska boxes out and controls the defensive side of the court. Illinois and Purdue are a cut above everyone else but those Huskers aren’t too far behind.
Now it is time to check out where Nebraska is on the other end. Spoiler alert, it’s not as good.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=big10, aes(x=reorder(Team, TeamOffRebounds), weight=TeamOffRebounds), fill="lightgrey") + 
  geom_bar(data=huskers, aes(x=reorder(Team, TeamOffRebounds), weight=TeamOffRebounds), fill="red") +
  coord_flip() +
 labs(
    title = "Downfall of the Huskers. Can't get second chances",
    subtitle = "Huskers finished 11th in offensive rebounds, not matching their production on the defensive end",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Offensive Rebounds",
    fill = "Rebound Type",
    caption = "Source | Basketball Reference | By: Caleb Clark"
    
  ) +
  theme_minimal()+
    theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face= "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size=10),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 8),  
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "white"),  
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "white") 
)









Is it a lack of effort, guys not following their shots? Something tells me it has to do with their lack of size too. No one on the roster was over the height of six foot nine. Boxing out can obviously get you rebounds on the defensive end as the Huskers have shown, but they have an issue at getting around other teams taller players when they are on offense.
Now instead of just seeing a small sample size like the Big Ten, how about we see where Nebraska ends up around the NCAA, against some of the top teams in the entire country.


Code
ncaa_rebounds <- basketball %>%
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten" |
           Conference == "SEC" |
           Conference == "Pac-12" |
           Conference == "ACC" |
           Conference == "WAC" |
           Conference == "Big 12" |
           Conference == "Sun Belt" |
           Conference == "SWAC" |
           Conference == "Summit" |
           Conference == "Southland" |
           Conference == "Patriot" |
           Conference == "OVC" |
           Conference == "NEC" |
           Conference == "MWC" |
           Conference == "MVC" |
           Conference == "MEAC" |
           Conference =="MAC" |
           Conference == "MAAC" |
           Conference == "Ivy" |
           Conference == "Independent" |
           Conference == "Horizon" |
           Conference == "CUSA" |
           Conference == "CAA" |
           Conference == "Big West" |
           Conference == "Big South" |
           Conference == "Big Sky" |
           Conference == "Big East" |
           Conference == "AEC" |
           Conference == "AAC" |
           Conference == "A-Sun" |
           Conference == "A-10"
        
         
        ) %>%
  group_by(Team) %>%
  summarise(
    Total_Offensive_Rebounds = sum(TeamOffRebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
    Total_Rebounds = sum(TeamTotalRebounds, na.rm = TRUE), 
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Rebounds), desc(Total_Offensive_Rebounds)) 

top_teams<-ncaa_rebounds %>% filter(Team=="Purdue"| Team=="Texas A&M"| Team=="Arizona"| Team=="Wisconsin"|Team=="Florida"| Team=="Connecticut"| Team=="Nebraska"| Team=="Rutgers")

rebound_totals<-ncaa_rebounds %>% inner_join(ncaa_rebounds, by=c("Team"))

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=ncaa_rebounds, aes(x=Total_Rebounds, y=Total_Offensive_Rebounds),color="lightgrey")+
  geom_point(data = top_teams, aes(x=Total_Rebounds, y=Total_Offensive_Rebounds),color="black")+
 geom_smooth(data = rebound_totals, aes(x=Total_Rebounds.x, y= Total_Offensive_Rebounds.y),method = "lm", se=FALSE)+
   geom_text(data=top_teams, aes(x=Total_Rebounds, y=Total_Offensive_Rebounds, label=Team))+
labs(
  x= "Total rebounds during the 2023-24 season",
  y="Offensive rebounds during 2023-24 season",
  title = "Huskers rebounding compared to top teams in NCAA",
  subtitle= "Nebraska ranks highly in total rebounds but you see their true defect in offensive rebounds",
  caption="Source | Basketball Reference | By: Caleb Clark"
)+
theme_minimal()+
    theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face= "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size=10),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 8), 
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "white"), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "white") 
)


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









As we can see, they are in the top percentile in defensive rebounding and it should continue to improve with added height to their 2024-2025 roster. But, can Coach Hoiberg figure out how to get more second chance opportunities which will lead to more points for the Huskers. If this trend continues, Nebraska will struggle to reach the goals they set for themselves.

title: Detroit Mercy was the worst College Basketball team last year. How?
text:
The Detroit Mercy Titans were the worst team during the 2023-2024 Men’s college basketball season with a record of 1-31. Their only win came on February 14th against conference opponent IUPUI by a score of 81-66 ending a 26 game losing streak.
My question was how and what led them to the worst record. Was it their offense, defense or a mix of both that crushed the Titans.
Lets take a look game by game to see how Detroit Mercy played against each opponent.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggrepel)
#| message: FALSE
basketball<- read_csv("logs24.csv")
detroitmercy <-basketball |>
  filter(Team == "Detroit Mercy")
gamedetroitmercy <- detroitmercy |> 
  group_by(Game, Team) |> 
  summarise(
    teampointscored = sum(TeamScore),
    opponentpointscored = sum(OpponentScore)
  ) |> 
  filter(Team == "Detroit Mercy")
gamedetroitmercy <- detroitmercy |> 
  group_by(Game) |> 
  summarise(
    teampointscored = sum(TeamScore[Team == "Detroit Mercy"]),
    opponentpointscored = sum(OpponentScore[Team == "Detroit Mercy"])
  )
df_long <- gamedetroitmercy |> 
  pivot_longer(cols = c("teampointscored", "opponentpointscored"),
               names_to = "Team",
               values_to = "Points")
df_long$Team <- recode(df_long$Team,
                       "teampointscored" = "Detroit Mercy",
                       "opponentpointscored" = "Opponent")
ggplot(df_long, aes(x = Game, y = Points, fill = Team)) + coord_flip() +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Detroit Mercy" = "blue", "Opponent" = "red")) +
  labs(title = "Detroit Mercy could not stop other teams from scoring",
       subtitle = "The Titans were consistently outscored by double digits, struggling to get stops",
       x = "Games Played",
       y = "Opponents Score plus Detroit Mercy's Score",
       caption = "Source: Basketball Reference | By Caleb Clark",
       fill = "Team") +
  theme_minimal()+
    theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face= "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size=10),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )









As we can see, the Titans often struggled to score but lost some close games along the way and were not blown out in every game. To lose almost every game, there has to be some bad luck along the way but what led to that for them?
Was it their offense that just couldn’t score or was it poor defense that led to them getting limited opportunities to score and make comebacks?
Let’s look at two stats that can show us where they were on the defensive end and keeping the ball. Steals and turnovers.


Code
turnovers_steals <- basketball %>%
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten" |
           Conference == "SEC" |
           Conference == "Pac-12" |
           Conference == "ACC" |
           Conference == "WAC" |
           Conference == "Big 12" |
           Conference == "Sun Belt" |
           Conference == "SWAC" |
           Conference == "Summit" |
           Conference == "Southland" |
           Conference == "Patriot" |
           Conference == "OVC" |
           Conference == "NEC" |
           Conference == "MWC" |
           Conference == "MVC" |
           Conference == "MEAC" |
           Conference =="MAC" |
           Conference == "MAAC" |
           Conference == "Ivy" |
           Conference == "Independent" |
           Conference == "Horizon" |
           Conference == "CUSA" |
           Conference == "CAA" |
           Conference == "Big West" |
           Conference == "Big South" |
           Conference == "Big Sky" |
           Conference == "Big East" |
           Conference == "AEC" |
           Conference == "AAC" |
           Conference == "A-Sun" |
           Conference == "A-10"
        
         
        ) %>%
  group_by(Team) %>%
  summarise(
    Total_Steals = sum(TeamSteals, na.rm = TRUE),
    Total_Turnovers = sum(TeamTurnovers, na.rm = TRUE), 
    Totalboth = sum(TeamTurnovers, TeamSteals, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Steals), desc(Total_Turnovers)) 

dmcolor<-turnovers_steals %>% filter(Team == "Detroit Mercy")

top_teams<-turnovers_steals %>% filter(Team=="Houston"| Team=="Nebraska"| Team=="Oakland"|Team=="IUPUI"| Team=="Connecticut" | Team=="Detroit Mercy")

ts_totals<-turnovers_steals %>% inner_join(basketball, by=c("Team"))
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=turnovers_steals, aes(x=Total_Steals, y=Total_Turnovers),color="lightgrey")+
  geom_point(data = dmcolor, aes(x=Total_Steals, y=Total_Turnovers), color="blue")+
  geom_point(data = top_teams, aes(x=Total_Steals, y=Total_Turnovers, size =Totalboth ),color="black")+
   geom_text_repel(data=top_teams, aes(x=Total_Steals, y=Total_Turnovers, label=Team))+
labs(
  x= "Total Steals during the 2023-24 season",
  y="Total Turnovers during 2023-24 season",
  title = "Turnovers and Steals not the issue for Titans",
  subtitle= "Detroit Mercy finished in the middle of the NCAA in both stats, better than some conference foes ",
  caption="Source | Basketball Reference | By: Caleb Clark"
)+
theme_minimal()+
    theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face= "bold", color = "black"),
    axis.title = element_text(size=10, color="black"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11, color="black"),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
)









The size of the dots add up both stats and you can see Detroit Mercy is very similar to teams like their conference champs Oakland and the Nebraska Cornhuskers who made the NCAA tournament.
So when it came to keeping the ball and taking it away, the Titans were average compared to all other teams in the NCAA. So if this is the case, what on their offensive side stopped them from winning any of these close games and improving their record.


Code
dm <- basketball |> filter(Team == "Detroit Mercy")
average <- basketball |> group_by(Date) |> summarise(mean_shooting=mean(Team3PPCT))

horizon <- basketball |> filter(Team == "Oakland" | Team == "IUPUI" | Team == "Mississippi Valley State")
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=horizon, aes(x=Date, y=Team3PPCT, group=Team), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=dm, aes(x=Date, y=Team3PPCT), color="blue") + 
  geom_line(data=average, aes(x=Date, y=mean_shooting), color="black")+
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, .7))+
labs(
 x= "Date",
 y="3-Point Shooting Percentage",
 title = "Shooting Struggles were the Main Issue for Detroit Mercy",
 subtitle= "Detroit Mercy's 3-point shooting trailed the league average and was bottom 5 nationally",
 caption="Source | Basketball Reference | By: Caleb Clark"
)+
theme_minimal()+
   theme(
   plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face= "bold", color = "black"),
   axis.title = element_text(size=10, color="black"),
   plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11, color="black"),
   plot.title.position = "plot",
   panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
)









Their main problem on offense was definitely three-point shooting, ranking fifth worst nationally at 28.1%. While they played pretty average defense and kept the ball out of their opponents hands, their offense let them down in the biggest moments and unfortunately led to them being the worst team in college basketball.
I do believe there was a good amount of bad luck to only win 1 out of 32 games, the Titans did not set themselves up to succeed offensively and it ultimately led to their worst season in franchise history dating back to 1909.
If they work on shooting and improve in that aspect, they should see an increase in wins immediately and produce better outcomes in the 24-25 season.
